title:
Spectral Radius of Graphs with Size Constraints: Resolving a Conjecture
  of Guiduli
authors: Rui Li, Anyao Wang, Mingqing Zhai
abstract:
A graph $G$ is said to satisfy the Hereditarily Bounded Property $P_{t,r}$
if, for every subgraph $H$ of $G$ with at least $t$ vertices, the size of $H$
satisfies $|E(H)| \leq t \cdot |V(H)| + r$. In 1996, Guiduli posed the
following problem: If an $n$-vertex graph $G$ possesses the property $P_{t,r}$,
where $t$ is a positive real number and $r$ is a real number such that $r \geq
-\binom{\lfloor t+1 \rfloor}{2}$, does it follow that the spectral radius
$\rho(G)$ is bounded above by $c(s,t) + \sqrt{\lfloor t \rfloor n}$, where $s =
\binom{t+1}{2} + r$?
  In this paper, we affirmatively resolve Guiduli's problem. Furthermore, we
provide a precise characterization of the extremal graphs that achieve this
bound. Specifically, these extremal graphs are constructed as the join of two
graphs: one being a complete graph $K_{\lfloor t \rfloor}$, and the other
either a disjoint union of $K_3$ and isolated vertices, or a forest consisting
solely of star structures.
  The forest of order $n-\lfloor t \rfloor$ in extremal graphs is meticulously
characterized. The key to our proof is the classification of the stars into
four categories--maximal, large, small, and minimal--according to their sizes.
This classification provides deeper insights into how edge distribution
influence the spectral properties of graphs under the constraint of property
$P_{t,r}$.
